page.title: 06St. Andrew,Lyddington.
page.content: This is a spacious and lofty building for a village,due to the rebuilding in the Perpendicular style of the nave and aisles in the late 15th century when the chancel arch was also rebuilt.The Tower topped by a dumpy broach spire,was erected in the first quarter of the 14th century.The chancel,of a similar age,was greatly changed by restoration in 1890.The wall painting behind the pulpit was uncovered in 1937 and may be of St.Edmund,King of the East Saxons, martyred and buried at Bury St.Edmunds in 870 AD,or more likely,King Edward the Confessor who died in 1042.There are 2 brasses in the chancel,one dated 1486 of Helyn Hardy and one 1520 of Edward Watson whose family acquired Rockingham Castle from Elizabeth I. There are still Watsons living there.
